title: @meddler How is ten bans fair?
body:
I don't think it's fair that you have just allowed for some people's mains and champions to be perma banned. Your excuse of  "diversity" Is a complete lie. Now it will be even less diverse. People won't be banning for "diversity", they will be banning based on champions they hate and have no skill to play against. I don't know how far you plan on allowing 10 bans, but if you think people outside of pro players will deal with it well you're kidding yourself. 

If you plan on making so many bans allowable, you have to create ban immunity for people not to feel stripped of their champions.

If a champion is permabanned (much like {{champion:38}} of old) then it spells out that there's a problem with that champion. It's a hint that the balance team should maybe look at the reasons why no one wants to play with/against that champion.

There's only one champion on that list of yours that would be a regular, and that's {{champion:157}} . Every other champion you've listed has come and gone according to their popularity and win rate. People already do their best to make Yasuo never see the light of day, so it's not like anything changed there either.

----

The real question is "how is anything less than 10 bans fair?" You don't get to ban a champion because of where you were randomly assigned in the pick order. You have to pick first and don't get to ban a champion that counters your intended pick.

10 bans, even if permabanned (worst case scenario), only hurts the mains of 10 champions. Everyone who mains or is comfortable on one of the other 120+ champions is fine.

Since Yasuo can only windwall one of my spells now, I'm able to actually play around him. A good Yasuo still leaves extremely little room to counterplay him, even if you do manage to counterpick him, you should know that.

Yasuo and LeBlanc are  the only ones on that list that are consistent bans. {{champion:164}} is a new champion, she'll stop being banned after she's been out a few patches. {{champion:120}} and {{champion:64}} are Junglers that are currently strong, they'll be swapped out when the meta shifts. Same goes for {{champion:51}} in her role as ADC. {{champion:55}} is mostly banned when she's strong and popular, just like {{champion:105}} {{champion:238}} {{champion:107}} {{champion:35}} or any other assassin. {{champion:17}} getting banned is a joke, on par with banning Urgot. {{champion:122}} and {{champion:92}} also rarely pull bans, most commonly by players who have recently had a bad experience against them. 

Yasuo has remained a constant ban (unless other priority bans shove him out) because of how hard he counters massive sections of the champion pool. His win rate is on par with LeBlanc's at 49.56%, he's certainly not weak.

It's perfectly right to ban champions you find annoying to play against or can't play against effectively. Why do you think MF Support got banned at Worlds? It was annoying, effective, and SKT didn't have a good counter to it.

If you don't like having your champion banned, go play Blind Pick or pick a less frustrating champion.

So that does influence the meta. This showcases more diversity since those champions feel more commonly picked.
